name: Machinelearningdemo
body:
### Welcome to Jackson's Machine Learning Demo
This is page is a demo of some of the applications of machine learning code I've written. Below each section is a demonstration of individual cases of each.

### Logistic Regression combined with Image Processing for Near-Pixel Prediction
In this I used a Logistic Regression (rounded at the end of computation) along with pre-computational image procession to predict what parts of the images fit the training data. In this specific example I used this to train the algorithm to predict what parts of an image are grass and which are not. To do this I gave it training data (pictures of grass and pictures of things without grass and labeled them respectively) and the algorithm then came up with parameters which allowed me to determine what part of an image (any image -- training data or not) has grass. For example, after I inputed the following images:




![Image a](https://i.imgsafe.org/1ca6da2109.jpg)
![Image b](https://i.imgsafe.org/1ca6e234fb.jpg)
![Image c](https://i.imgsafe.org/1ca6eb5f9a.jpg)
![Image d](https://i.imgsafe.org/1ca6f1a2dc.jpg)



The algorithm outputed these images:




![Image a](https://i.imgsafe.org/1c9906befa.jpg)
![Image b](https://i.imgsafe.org/1c990db67a.jpg)
![Image c](https://i.imgsafe.org/1c99160f30.jpg)
![Image d](https://i.imgsafe.org/1c9922c3cc.jpg)



*Note that white corresponds to grass and black corresponds the opposite.

As you can see this algorithm is not perfect but shows a rough approximation and it can easily be imagined in autonomous lawnmowers (because the image input would be a smaller image of mostly grass and only dirt or flowers would be the items it would have to filter), for estimating acreage of grass on land, etc.

### Authors and Contributors
